subtitle: Make a plan for labour
title: Month 7
content:
Created by Baby Center

Now your baby can open her eyes and turn her head towards light, even in the
womb! She can hear now, and may kick and jump when she hears loud sounds, and
settle down when you sing and talk to her. Soon she will get into a head-down
position inside you. Her head will be born first, so she turns upside down,
ready for labour to begin. As your bump gets bigger, it may be difficult to
get comfortable and sleep well. Lie on your side and put a pillow between your
legs so your bump is supported. You may start to feel some hip pain because
the stretchy body tissue holding your hips to your pelvis may loosen. This is
your body preparing for labour. Kneeling on your hands and knees may help. You
will need to make a plan for going to the midwife or doctor in labour. Plan
how you will travel there, and perhaps ask a friend or relative if they will
help. Talk to your family and make sure they know where you need to go. Go to
the health facility in late pregnancy so the nurse or health worker can check
that you and the baby are well. They can tell you what you need for the birth
and when to go to the clinic in labour.
